content: I am currently using pip version 10.0.1. However, when I run a pip install script, I get a warning message saying "You are using pip version 10.0.1, however version 18.0 is available". I find this quite strange. Did the pip project just suddenly upgrade from version 10 to version 18? If so, why did this happen?

Yes, it can be quite surprising to see such a large jump in version numbers. The pip project did indeed make a significant leap in versioning from 10.x to 18.x. This change was part of a new versioning scheme adopted by the project.

Historically, pip followed a more traditional versioning sequence, but the developers decided to align the version numbers more closely with the Python Packaging Authority (PyPA) tools and standards. This change was to ensure that pip's version numbers more accurately reflected the pace of its development and updates.

By adopting a new versioning strategy, the pip maintainers aimed to reduce confusion about the tool's maturity and to encourage more frequent updates. This is why you noticed the jump from version 10 to 18.

To avoid any issues and to benefit from the latest features, improvements, and security patches, it's generally a good idea to keep your pip installation up to date. You can update pip with the following command:

```bash
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
```

This will upgrade your pip to the latest available version.
